canonical_explanation.text: Natural resources can be classified as exhaustible (limited in nature, will run out) and inexhaustible (unlimited, will not run out). Coal, petroleum, and natural gas are exhaustible resources called fossil fuels because they were formed from the remains of dead organisms over millions of years. Coal was formed by the carbonisation of dead vegetation buried deep under the earth. It exists in types of increasing carbon content: peat, lignite, bituminous, and anthracite. When coal is processed in the absence of air (destructive distillation), it yields coke, coal tar, and coal gas. Petroleum (meaning 'rock oil') was formed from dead marine organisms compressed under sedimentary rocks. It is refined by fractional distillation to yield various fractions including LPG, petrol, diesel, kerosene, lubricating oil, paraffin wax, and bitumen. Natural gas, mainly methane, is found above petroleum deposits and is used as CNG (Compressed Natural Gas) — a cleaner fuel. Conservation of these resources is essential since they take millions of years to form.
rules: Exhaustible resources are limited and will run out; inexhaustible resources are unlimited.
Fossil fuels (coal, petroleum, natural gas) formed from dead organisms over millions of years.
Coal formed by carbonisation of dead vegetation; types: peat, lignite, bituminous, anthracite.
Destructive distillation of coal yields coke, coal tar, and coal gas.
Coke is used in steel making; coal tar gives dyes, drugs, perfumes; coal gas was used for lighting.
Petroleum formed from dead marine organisms under high pressure and temperature.
Fractional distillation of petroleum yields LPG, petrol, kerosene, diesel, lubricating oil, paraffin wax, bitumen.
Natural gas (mainly methane) is used as CNG, a cleaner fuel than petrol or diesel.
Petrochemicals are products derived from petroleum and natural gas.
PCRA (Petroleum Conservation Research Association) advises on saving fuel.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an exhaustible natural resource?
questions.explanation_correct: Coal is an exhaustible natural resource because it is available in limited quantities and will eventually run out. It takes millions of years to form, so once used, it cannot be replenished quickly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sunlight, wind, and water are inexhaustible resources — they are available in unlimited quantities and are continuously replenished by nature. Coal, a fossil fuel, is exhaustible because its supply is finite.

questions.question_text: What are fossil fuels?

options.text: Fuels formed from dead organisms over millions of years

questions.explanation_correct: Fossil fuels are fuels that were formed from the remains of dead plants and animals buried under the earth millions of years ago. Coal, petroleum, and natural gas are the three main fossil fuels.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fossil fuels are not man-made or derived from sunlight. They formed naturally over millions of years from the decomposition and compression of dead organisms under high pressure and temperature deep within the earth.

questions.question_text: The process by which dead vegetation slowly converted into coal is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Carbonisation is the slow process by which dead vegetation buried deep under the earth gradually converted into coal over millions of years. The high temperature and pressure underground drove off moisture and increased the carbon content.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Distillation is used to separate liquids. Combustion is burning. Evaporation is liquid to gas conversion. Carbonisation specifically refers to the geological process of dead plant matter gradually turning into carbon-rich coal.

questions.question_text: Which type of coal has the highest carbon content?
questions.explanation_correct: Anthracite has the highest carbon content (about 90-95%) among all types of coal. The carbon content increases in the order: peat < lignite < bituminous < anthracite, with anthracite being the hardest and best quality coal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Peat has the lowest carbon content and is the earliest stage of coal formation. Lignite and bituminous have intermediate carbon content. Anthracite, the final stage, has the maximum carbon content and produces the most heat.

questions.question_text: Which product of coal is used in the manufacture of steel?
questions.explanation_correct: Coke is a tough, porous, and black substance that is almost pure carbon. It is obtained from the destructive distillation of coal and is widely used in steel making as a reducing agent to extract iron from its ore.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Coal tar is used for dyes, drugs, and road surfaces. Coal gas was used for street lighting. Peat is a type of coal, not a product. Coke is the specific coal product used in steel manufacturing.

questions.question_text: Coal tar is a source of many useful substances. Which of the following is obtained from coal tar?
questions.explanation_correct: Coal tar is a thick, black liquid with a strong smell obtained from the destructive distillation of coal. It is a mixture of about 200 different substances and serves as a starting material for making dyes, drugs, perfumes, explosives, paints, and plastics.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Petrol, natural gas, and lubricating oil are obtained from petroleum, not coal tar. Coal tar specifically yields substances used in the chemical industry including synthetic dyes, pharmaceutical drugs, perfumes, and naphthalene balls.

questions.question_text: What does the word 'petroleum' literally mean?
questions.explanation_correct: The word 'petroleum' comes from Latin: 'petra' meaning rock and 'oleum' meaning oil. So petroleum literally means 'rock oil'. It is found trapped between layers of rock deep underground.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While petroleum is sometimes called 'black gold' due to its value, its literal meaning is 'rock oil' from the Latin words petra (rock) and oleum (oil). It is neither liquid coal nor earth fuel.

questions.question_text: How was petroleum formed?

options.text: From dead marine organisms under high pressure and temperature

questions.explanation_correct: Petroleum was formed from the remains of dead marine organisms (tiny sea plants and animals) that sank to the ocean floor millions of years ago. Over time, they were covered by layers of sand and clay, and the high pressure and temperature converted them into petroleum.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Coal (not petroleum) was formed from dead land plants. Petroleum specifically formed from dead marine organisms. It was not produced by volcanic eruptions or meteors but through a gradual geological process over millions of years.

questions.question_text: The process used to separate petroleum into its different components is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Fractional distillation is the process used to refine petroleum. Since petroleum is a mixture of various hydrocarbons with different boiling points, heating it causes different components to vaporise and condense at different temperatures, separating them into fractions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Carbonisation is the formation of coal. Filtration separates solids from liquids. Evaporation is for removing solvent. Fractional distillation is the specific technique used in petroleum refineries to separate crude oil into useful fractions.

questions.question_text: Which petroleum fraction has the lowest boiling point and is obtained at the top of the fractionating column?
questions.explanation_correct: LPG (Liquefied Petroleum Gas) has the lowest boiling point among petroleum fractions and is collected at the top of the fractionating column. Fractions with lower boiling points rise to the top, while heavier fractions like bitumen remain at the bottom.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bitumen has the highest boiling point and is collected at the bottom. Diesel and lubricating oil have intermediate to high boiling points. LPG, being the lightest fraction, has the lowest boiling point and rises to the top of the column.

questions.question_text: Which petroleum product is used for surfacing roads?
questions.explanation_correct: Bitumen (also called asphalt or tar) is the heaviest fraction obtained from petroleum refining. It is a thick, black, sticky residue used for surfacing roads and waterproofing roofs. It is obtained at the bottom of the fractionating column.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Petrol is used as motor fuel. Kerosene is used for cooking and aviation fuel. LPG is used for cooking gas. Bitumen, the heaviest and least volatile fraction of petroleum, is the one used for road construction.

questions.question_text: What is the main component of natural gas?
questions.explanation_correct: Methane is the main component of natural gas, making up about 80-90% of its composition. Natural gas is found above petroleum deposits and is used as CNG (Compressed Natural Gas) for vehicles and as fuel in homes and industries.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While ethane, propane, and butane are present in natural gas in small amounts, methane is the dominant component, constituting about 80-90% of natural gas.

questions.question_text: CNG stands for:
questions.explanation_correct: CNG stands for Compressed Natural Gas. It is natural gas (mainly methane) that has been compressed to a high pressure for use as a fuel in vehicles. CNG is considered a cleaner fuel because it produces less pollution than petrol or diesel.
questions.explanation_incorrect: CNG stands for Compressed Natural Gas, not any of the other options. It is widely used in public transport vehicles in India as an alternative to petrol and diesel because it burns more cleanly.

questions.question_text: Why is CNG considered a better fuel than petrol or diesel?

options.text: CNG is a cleaner fuel that produces less air pollution

questions.explanation_correct: CNG is considered better than petrol or diesel because it burns more completely, producing less carbon dioxide and almost no particulate matter or sulphur dioxide. This makes it a cleaner fuel that causes significantly less air pollution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: CNG is actually cheaper than petrol. It does not produce more smoke — in fact, it produces much less. CNG is a gaseous fuel, not solid. Its main advantage is being environmentally cleaner with lower emissions.

questions.question_text: Why are fossil fuels considered non-renewable resources?

options.text: Because they take millions of years to form and cannot be replenished quickly
Because they are found only in India

questions.explanation_correct: Fossil fuels are non-renewable because they took millions of years to form from dead organisms under specific geological conditions. Once used up, they cannot be replaced within a human timescale, making their conservation essential.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fossil fuels are non-renewable not because of cost, location, or usefulness, but because the geological process that created them took millions of years. At our current rate of consumption, these resources will eventually be exhausted.

questions.question_text: What is destructive distillation of coal?

options.text: Heating coal in the absence of air to obtain coke, coal tar, and coal gas

questions.explanation_correct: Destructive distillation of coal is the process of heating coal strongly in the absence of air. This breaks down coal into three useful products: coke (solid residue, almost pure carbon), coal tar (thick black liquid), and coal gas (a mixture of gases).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Burning coal in air is combustion, not destructive distillation. The key difference is that destructive distillation is done in the absence of air, which prevents combustion and instead decomposes coal into coke, coal tar, and coal gas.

questions.question_text: Which petroleum fraction is used as fuel for jet aeroplanes?
questions.explanation_correct: Kerosene is used as aviation fuel (jet fuel) for aeroplanes. It has a moderate boiling point and provides efficient combustion at high altitudes. Kerosene is also used in stoves and lamps in many households.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Petrol is used in cars and motorcycles. Diesel is used in trucks and generators. LPG is used for cooking. Kerosene, also known as aviation turbine fuel (ATF) when refined for aviation, is the fuel used in jet engines.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a fossil fuel?
questions.explanation_correct: Wood is not a fossil fuel. Fossil fuels (coal, petroleum, natural gas) were formed from the remains of dead organisms over millions of years underground. Wood comes from living trees and is a renewable (though exhaustible) resource.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Coal, petroleum, and natural gas are all fossil fuels formed from ancient organisms over geological time periods. Wood is obtained from current living trees and, while it can be used as fuel, it is not classified as a fossil fuel.

questions.question_text: Arrange the types of coal in increasing order of carbon content.
questions.explanation_correct: The correct increasing order of carbon content is Peat < Lignite < Bituminous < Anthracite. Peat is the earliest stage with the least carbon, while anthracite is the most mature form with the highest carbon content (about 90-95%).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Coal formation progresses from peat (least carbon, earliest stage) through lignite and bituminous coal to anthracite (most carbon, final stage). Each successive type has higher carbon content and better fuel value.

questions.question_text: During fractional distillation of petroleum, which fraction is obtained at the bottom of the fractionating column?
questions.explanation_correct: Bitumen is obtained at the bottom of the fractionating column because it has the highest boiling point among petroleum fractions. In fractional distillation, heavier fractions with higher boiling points settle at the bottom, while lighter fractions rise to the top.
questions.explanation_incorrect: LPG and petrol have low boiling points and are collected near the top. Kerosene is collected in the middle. Bitumen, being the heaviest and most viscous fraction, has the highest boiling point and remains at the bottom of the column.

questions.question_text: What are petrochemicals?

options.text: Chemicals and materials derived from petroleum and natural gas
Chemicals found in coal tar only

questions.explanation_correct: Petrochemicals are chemicals and useful materials derived from petroleum and natural gas. They include synthetic fibres (polyester, nylon), plastics, detergents, drugs, dyes, and many other products used in daily life.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Petrochemicals are not used to find or destroy petroleum. While some chemicals come from coal tar, petrochemicals specifically refer to the wide range of products derived from petroleum and natural gas processing.

questions.question_text: PCRA advises people to save fuel. What does PCRA stand for?
questions.explanation_correct: PCRA stands for Petroleum Conservation Research Association. It is an Indian body that advises people on how to save petrol, diesel, and other fuels in transport, industry, and home through better practices and technology.
questions.explanation_incorrect: PCRA stands for Petroleum Conservation Research Association. It focuses on promoting fuel conservation awareness in India and provides guidelines for efficient use of petroleum products.

questions.question_text: LPG used in homes for cooking is obtained from:
questions.explanation_correct: LPG (Liquefied Petroleum Gas) is obtained as a fraction during the refining of petroleum by fractional distillation. It is mainly a mixture of butane and propane, supplied in pressurised cylinders for domestic cooking.
questions.explanation_incorrect: LPG is not obtained from coal, wood, or solar energy. It is a petroleum product obtained at the top of the fractionating column during petroleum refining. LPG stands for Liquefied Petroleum Gas.

questions.question_text: Which product of coal was earlier used for street lighting?
questions.explanation_correct: Coal gas was used for street lighting in many cities until the development of electric lighting. It is obtained as a by-product during the destructive distillation of coal and burns with a bright flame.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Coke is a solid used in steel making. Coal tar is a liquid used in the chemical industry. Anthracite is a type of coal. Coal gas is the product that was historically used for lighting streets and homes before electricity became common.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an inexhaustible resource?
questions.explanation_correct: Solar energy is an inexhaustible resource because the sun will continue to provide energy for billions of years. It is continuously available and will not run out unlike fossil fuels.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Petroleum, coal, and natural gas are all exhaustible fossil fuels with limited reserves. Solar energy is inexhaustible — the sun produces an enormous amount of energy continuously, making it a renewable and unlimited resource.

questions.question_text: Petroleum is referred to as 'black gold' because:

options.text: It is black in colour and found with gold
It is dark in colour and extremely valuable commercially
It turns into gold when heated

questions.explanation_correct: Petroleum is called 'black gold' because of its dark colour and its enormous commercial value. It is a crucial resource for energy, transport, and the manufacturing of thousands of products, making it as valuable as gold to the global economy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Petroleum is not found with gold, does not turn into gold, and is dark black in colour — not golden. The nickname 'black gold' refers to its black appearance combined with its immense economic value and importance.

questions.question_text: Natural gas is stored under high pressure as CNG. This is transported through:
questions.explanation_correct: Natural gas is primarily transported through pipelines, which is the most efficient and common method. Large networks of pipelines carry natural gas from production sites to cities, industries, and CNG filling stations across the country.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While natural gas can be transported in compressed cylinders by road or in liquefied form by ships, pipelines are the primary and most efficient method for transporting natural gas over long distances.

questions.question_text: Which product of coal processing is almost pure carbon?
questions.explanation_correct: Coke is almost pure carbon. It is a tough, porous, black substance obtained by the destructive distillation of coal. Due to its high carbon content, coke is an excellent fuel and reducing agent used in metallurgy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Coal tar is a complex mixture of many chemicals. Coal gas is a mixture of gases including hydrogen and methane. Lignite is a type of coal with low carbon content. Coke, produced by heating coal without air, is the product that is almost pure carbon.

questions.question_text: Why should we conserve fossil fuels? Which answer gives the BEST reason?

options.text: Because they are exhaustible, take millions of years to form, and their burning causes pollution
Because they are difficult to transport
Because they are available only in one country

questions.explanation_correct: Fossil fuels should be conserved because they are exhaustible (limited supply), take millions of years to form (cannot be replenished quickly), and their burning releases harmful pollutants causing air pollution, acid rain, and global warming. Conservation ensures they last longer and reduces environmental damage.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The main reasons for conservation are not cost, transport difficulty, or geographic availability. The critical factors are that fossil fuels are finite, non-renewable within human timescales, and their combustion causes significant environmental damage.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the correct order of petroleum fractions from lowest to highest boiling point?
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order from lowest to highest boiling point is LPG < Petrol < Kerosene < Diesel < Bitumen. In fractional distillation, fractions with lower boiling points are collected at the top and those with higher boiling points at the bottom.
questions.explanation_incorrect: LPG has the lowest boiling point and bitumen has the highest. The order reflects how fractions separate in the fractionating column: lighter fractions (LPG, petrol) at the top, medium fractions (kerosene, diesel) in the middle, and heavy fractions (bitumen) at the bottom.

questions.question_text: Coal, petroleum, and natural gas are called fossil fuels.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. Coal, petroleum, and natural gas are called fossil fuels because they were formed from the fossils (remains) of dead organisms — plants and animals — that lived millions of years ago.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is correct. These three resources are collectively called fossil fuels because they were formed from ancient organic remains (fossils) over geological time periods through heat and pressure.

questions.question_text: Coal tar is a thick black liquid obtained by the destructive distillation of coal.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. Coal tar is indeed a thick, black, strong-smelling liquid obtained as a by-product during the destructive distillation of coal. It contains about 200 different chemical substances.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is accurate. Coal tar is one of the three products (along with coke and coal gas) obtained when coal is heated strongly in the absence of air through destructive distillation.

questions.question_text: Petroleum is formed from dead land plants buried under the earth.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Petroleum was formed from dead marine organisms (tiny plants and animals that lived in the sea), not from land plants. It is coal that was formed from dead land plants. Petroleum formed when marine organisms sank to the ocean floor and were covered by sediments over millions of years.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Coal was formed from dead land plants, not petroleum. Petroleum was formed from the remains of tiny marine organisms that died and settled on the sea floor millions of years ago, where they were subjected to high pressure and temperature.

questions.question_text: CNG is considered a cleaner fuel because it produces less air pollution compared to petrol and diesel.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. CNG (Compressed Natural Gas) is a cleaner fuel because when burned, it produces fewer pollutants like carbon monoxide, sulphur dioxide, and particulate matter compared to petrol and diesel, resulting in less air pollution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: CNG is indeed cleaner than petrol and diesel. It undergoes more complete combustion and produces significantly lower amounts of harmful emissions including unburnt hydrocarbons, carbon monoxide, and particulate matter.

questions.question_text: Sunlight and wind energy are exhaustible resources that will eventually run out.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Sunlight and wind energy are inexhaustible resources. They are continuously available in nature and will not run out within foreseeable time. The sun will continue to shine for billions of years.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sunlight and wind are inexhaustible (unlimited) resources, not exhaustible. They are continuously replenished by natural processes and are available in virtually unlimited supply, unlike fossil fuels which are finite.

questions.question_text: During destructive distillation of coal, the coal is heated in the presence of excess air.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Destructive distillation of coal is carried out in the absence of air, not in the presence of air. Heating coal in air would cause combustion (burning), not distillation. The absence of air allows coal to decompose into coke, coal tar, and coal gas without burning.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If coal were heated in air, it would simply burn (combustion). Destructive distillation requires the absence of air so that the coal decomposes thermally into its useful components without burning away.

questions.question_text: The slow process of conversion of dead vegetation into coal is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Carbonisation is the geological process by which dead vegetation was slowly converted into coal over millions of years. The remains of plants were buried under layers of earth, and the high pressure and temperature gradually increased their carbon content.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer is 'carbonisation'. This slow, natural process took place over millions of years as dead plants were buried, compressed, and heated underground, gradually converting them into carbon-rich coal.

questions.question_text: The separation of petroleum into its different components is done by ___ distillation.
questions.explanation_correct: Fractional distillation is used to separate petroleum into its components (fractions) based on their different boiling points. This process takes place in a fractionating column at petroleum refineries.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer is 'fractional'. Fractional distillation works because different components of petroleum have different boiling points, allowing them to be separated by heating crude oil and collecting vapours at different temperatures.

questions.question_text: The main component of natural gas is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Methane is the main component of natural gas, constituting about 80-90% of its composition. Methane is the simplest hydrocarbon with the formula CH4, and it burns cleanly to produce heat.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer is 'methane'. While natural gas contains small amounts of ethane, propane, and butane, methane is by far the dominant component.

questions.question_text: The three products of destructive distillation of coal are coke, coal tar, and ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The three products obtained from the destructive distillation of coal are coke (solid, almost pure carbon), coal tar (thick black liquid), and coal gas (mixture of gases including hydrogen and methane). Coal gas was historically used for street lighting.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer is 'coal gas'. When coal is heated in the absence of air, it decomposes into three products: coke (solid), coal tar (liquid), and coal gas (gaseous mixture).

questions.question_text: The heaviest fraction of petroleum used for road surfacing is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Bitumen (also known as asphalt) is the heaviest fraction obtained at the bottom of the fractionating column during petroleum refining. It has the highest boiling point and is used for surfacing roads and waterproofing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer is 'bitumen'. It is the residue left at the bottom of the fractionating column after all lighter fractions have been collected. Bitumen is thick, black, and sticky, making it ideal for road construction.

questions.question_text: Which petroleum product is used in homes as cooking gas in cylinders?
questions.explanation_correct: LPG (Liquefied Petroleum Gas) is supplied in pressurised cylinders for domestic cooking. It is a mixture of butane and propane obtained from petroleum refining. LPG burns with a clean blue flame and is widely used in Indian households.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Petrol is used in vehicles. Diesel is used in heavy vehicles and generators. Bitumen is used for roads. LPG is the petroleum product specifically supplied in cylinders for cooking in homes.

questions.question_text: Which of the following actions helps conserve fossil fuels?

options.text: Using private cars for short distances
Keeping vehicles running when not in use
Using public transport, cycling, or walking for short distances
Using more fossil fuels to create more

questions.explanation_correct: Using public transport, cycling, or walking for short distances reduces the consumption of petrol and diesel, helping conserve fossil fuels. These practices also reduce air pollution and traffic congestion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using private cars for short distances and keeping engines running waste fuel. More fossil fuels cannot be created — they take millions of years to form. Public transport, cycling, and walking are effective conservation strategies.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a use of natural gas?

options.text: As raw material for fertiliser production
As a substitute for iron in construction

questions.explanation_correct: Natural gas cannot substitute for iron in construction. Iron is a structural metal with physical strength. Natural gas is used as CNG fuel, for power generation, and as raw material for producing hydrogen and fertilisers like urea.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Natural gas is used as CNG in vehicles, for power generation, and in fertiliser manufacturing. However, it cannot replace iron in construction since iron provides structural strength while natural gas is a fuel/chemical feedstock.

questions.question_text: Naphthalene balls used to repel moths are obtained from:
questions.explanation_correct: Naphthalene balls are obtained from coal tar, which is a product of the destructive distillation of coal. Coal tar contains about 200 different chemical substances, including naphthalene, which is used to make moth-repelling balls.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Naphthalene is not derived from petroleum, natural gas, or coke. It is one of the many useful chemicals extracted from coal tar during the processing of coal.

questions.question_text: Which petroleum fraction is used as lubricant for machine parts?
questions.explanation_correct: Lubricating oil is a petroleum fraction obtained during fractional distillation. It has a high boiling point, is viscous (thick), and is used to reduce friction between moving parts of machines and engines.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Petrol and kerosene are fuels. LPG is cooking gas. Lubricating oil is the specific petroleum fraction designed to reduce friction and wear in machinery and engines.

questions.question_text: Resources that are available in unlimited quantity in nature are called ___ resources.
questions.explanation_correct: Inexhaustible resources are those available in unlimited quantities and cannot be used up by human activities. Examples include sunlight, wind energy, and tidal energy. They are continuously replenished by natural processes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer is 'inexhaustible'. These resources are in unlimited supply, unlike exhaustible resources (fossil fuels) that exist in finite quantities and will eventually run out.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about coke is correct?

options.text: Coke is a liquid obtained from coal
Coke is a tough, porous, black solid that is almost pure carbon
Coke is a gas used for lighting
Coke is a type of petroleum product

questions.explanation_correct: Coke is a tough, porous, black solid that is almost pure carbon. It is obtained from the destructive distillation of coal and is used as a fuel and as a reducing agent in steel manufacturing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Coke is not a liquid (that is coal tar), not a gas (that is coal gas), and not a petroleum product. It is a solid residue from coal processing, valued for its high carbon content and use in metallurgy.

questions.question_text: Petroleum is a mixture of only two substances — petrol and diesel.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Petroleum is a complex mixture of many different hydrocarbons, not just two substances. When refined by fractional distillation, it yields many fractions including LPG, petrol, kerosene, diesel, lubricating oil, paraffin wax, and bitumen.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Petroleum contains many different hydrocarbon compounds, not just petrol and diesel. Fractional distillation separates it into numerous useful fractions, each with different properties and uses.

questions.question_text: Coal, petroleum, and natural gas are collectively known as ___ fuels.
questions.explanation_correct: Coal, petroleum, and natural gas are collectively known as fossil fuels because they were formed from the remains (fossils) of ancient plants and animals over millions of years under heat and pressure.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer is 'fossil'. These fuels are called fossil fuels because they originated from the preserved remains of prehistoric organisms that lived millions of years ago.
